clinical_study.brief_title: Combination of Water Immersion and Carbon Dioxide Insufflation for Minimal Sedation Colonoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Combination of Water Immersion and Carbon Dioxide Insufflation for Minimal Sedation Colonoscopy - a Prospective, Randomized, Single-center Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
Water immersion insertion and carbon dioxide (CO2)instead of room air insufflation as alternative colonoscopy techniques have been documented to decrease patient discomfort during and after the procedure.
This prospective, randomized, single-center trial was designed to evaluate whether the combination of water immersion during insertion and CO2 insufflation during withdrawal (Water/CO2)for minimal sedation colonoscopy (2 mg of midazolam i.v.)is superior to the other colonoscopy methods (Water/Air, CO2/CO2, Air/Air).

primary_outcome.measure: Success Rate of Minimal Sedation Colonoscopy
primary_outcome.description: Successful minimal sedation colonoscopy using assigned technique was defined as reaching the caecum without switch to another insertion method and / or without additional sedation beyond the initial administration of 2 mg of midazolam.

primary_outcome.measure: Success Rate of Minimal Sedation Colonoscopy
primary_outcome.description: A succesful colonoscopy using assigned technique was defined as reaching the caecum without switching to another insertion method and without additional sedation beyond the initial 2 mg of midazolam. Any time the further insertion of the scope was not possible, the patient reported pain level > 3 using a 7-point Likert scale [7] (0 = no pain, 6 = intolerable pain) or demanded additional sedation, the endoscopist preferentially switched to the other insertion technique. Enhanced sedation was used in case the other technique had not been successful.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Comfort During the Procedure and During First 24 Hours After Procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Comfort was assessed using a 18-point questionnaire form based on 0-6 continuous scale (0 = best, 6 = worst)- abdominal pain during, 30 minutes, 3, 12 and 24 hours after the procedure, bloating duringm 30 minutes, 3, 12 and 24 hours after the procedure, flatus during, 30 minutes, 3, 12 and 24 hours after the procedure, impact on patient´s daily activities during first 24 hours after the procedure, willingnes to repeat the colonoscopy and overall satisfaction with the procedure

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- men and women older than 18 years referred for diagnostic outpatient colonoscopy
- provided written consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- history of colorectal surgery
- known diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease
- chronic benzodiazepine use
- refusal of minimal sedation
